zùëßz-SignFedAvg: A Unified Stochastic Sign-based Compression for Federated Learning

Zhiwei Tang
zhiweitang1@link.cuhk.edu.cn
&Yanmeng Wang
yanmengwang@link.cuhk.edu.cn
&Tsung-Hui Chang
changtsunghui@cuhk.edu.cn
\ANDThe Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a promising privacy-preserving distributed learning paradigm but suffers from high communication cost when training large-scale machine learning models. Sign-based methods, such as SignSGD [9], have been proposed as a biased gradient compression technique for reducing the communication cost. However, sign-based algorithms could diverge under heterogeneous data, which thus motivated the development of advanced techniques, such as the error-feedback method and stochastic sign-based compression, to fix this issue. Nevertheless, these methods still suffer from slower convergence rates. Besides, none of them allows multiple local SGD updates like FedAvg [37]. In this paper, we propose a novel noisy perturbation scheme with a general symmetric noise distribution for sign-based compression, which not only allows one to flexibly control the tradeoff between gradient bias and convergence performance, but also provides a unified viewpoint to existing stochastic sign-based methods. More importantly, the unified noisy perturbation scheme enables the development of the very first sign-based FedAvg algorithm (zùëßz-SignFedAvg) to accelerate the convergence. Theoretically, we show that zùëßz-SignFedAvg achieves a faster convergence rate than existing sign-based methods and, under the uniformly distributed noise, can enjoy the same convergence rate as its uncompressed counterpart. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate that the zùëßz-SignFedAvg can achieve competitive empirical performance on real datasets and outperforms existing schemes.

1 Introduction

We consider the Federated Learning (FL) network with one parameter server and nùëõn clients [37, 34], with the focus on solving the following distributed learning problem

minx‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°f‚Äã(x)=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1nfi‚Äã(x),subscriptùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëùëìùë•1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëìùëñùë•\displaystyle\min_{x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}}f(x)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x), (1)

where fi‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëìùëñ‚ãÖf_{i}(\cdot) is the local objective function for the iùëñi-th client, for i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n. Throughout this paper, we assume that each fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} is smooth and possibly non-convex. The local objective functions are generated from the local dataset owned by each client. When designing distributed algorithms to solve (1), a crucial aspect is the communication efficiency since a massive number of clients need to transmit their local gradients to the server frequently [34]. As one of the most popular FL algorithms, the federated averaging (FedAvg) algorithm [37, 32] considers multiple local SGD updates with periodic communications to reduce the communication cost. Another way is to compress the local gradients before sending them to the server [34, 5, 42]. Among the existing compression methods, a simple yet elegant technique is to take the sign of each coordinate of the local gradients, which requires only one bit for transmitting each coordinate. For any x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in{\mathbb{R}}, we define the sign operator as: Sign‚Äã(x)=1‚Äã¬†if¬†‚Äãx‚â•0Signùë•1¬†if¬†ùë•0\text{Sign}(x)=1\text{ if }x\geq 0 and ‚àí11-1 otherwise.

It has been shown recently that optimization algorithms with the sign-based compression can enjoy a great communication efficiency while still achieving comparable empirical performance as uncompressed algorithms [9, 31, 43]. However, for distributed learning, especially the scenarios with heterogeneous data, i.e., fi‚â†fjsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùëìùëóf_{i}\neq f_{j} for every i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j, a naive application of the sign-based algorithm may end up with divergence [31, 12, 43].

A counterexample for sign-based distributed gradient descent. Consider the one-dimensional problem with two clients: minx‚àà‚Ñù(x‚àíA)2+(x+A)2\min_{x\in{\mathbb{R}}}\ (x-A)^{2}+(x+A)^{2}, where A>0ùê¥0A>0 is some constant. For any x‚àà[‚àíA,A]ùë•ùê¥ùê¥x\in[-A,A], the averaged sign gradient at xùë•x is Sign‚Äã(x‚àíA)+Sign‚Äã(x+A)=0,Signùë•ùê¥Signùë•ùê¥0\text{Sign}(x-A)+\text{Sign}(x+A)=0, i.e., the algorithm never moves. Similar examples are also discussed by [12, 43]. The fundamental reason for this undesirable result is the uncontrollable bias brought by the sign-based compression.

There are mainly two approaches to fixing this issue in the existing literature. The first one is the stochastic sign-based method, which introduces stochasticity into the sign operation [27, 43, 12], and the second one is the Error-Feedback (EF) method [31, 50, 47]. However, these works are still unsatisfactory. Specifically, on one hand, both the theoretical convergence rates and empirical performance of these algorithms are still worse than uncompressed algorithms like [22, 55]. On the other hand, none of them allows the clients to have multiple local SGD updates within one communication round like the FedAvg, which thereby are less communication efficient. This work aims at addressing these issues and closing the gaps for sign-based methods.

Main contributions. Our contributions are summarized as follows.

  1. (1)

    A unified family of stochastic sign operators. We show an intriguing fact: The bias brought by the sign-based compression can be flexibly controlled by injecting a proper amount of random noise before the sign operation. In particular, our analysis is based on a novel noisy perturbation scheme with a general symmetric noise distribution, which also provides a unified framework to understand existing stochastic sign-based methods including [27, 43, 12].

  2. (2)

    The first sign-based FedAvg algorithm. In contrast to the existing sign-based methods which do not allow multiple local SGD updates within one communication round, based on the proposed stochastic sign-based compression, we design a novel family of sign-based federated averaging algorithms (zùëßz-SignFedAvg) that can achieve the best of both worlds: high communication efficiency and fast convergence rate.

  3. (3)

    New theoretical convergence rate analyses. By leveraging the asymptotic unbiasedness property of the stochastic sign-based compression, we derive a series of theoretical results for zùëßz-SignFedAvg and demonstrate its improved convergence rates over the existing sign-based methods. In particular, we show that by injecting a sufficiently large uniform noise, zùëßz-SignFedAvg can have a matching convergence rate with the uncompressed algorithms.

Organization. In Section 2, the proposed general noisy perturbation scheme for the sign-based compression and its key property, i.e., asymptotic unbiasedness, are presented. Inspired by this result, the main algorithms are devised in Section 3 together with their convergence analyses under different noise distribution parameters. We evaluate our proposed algorithms on real datasets and benchmarks with existing sign-based methods in Section 4. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section 5.

Notations. For any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, we denote x‚Äã(j)ùë•ùëóx(j) as the jùëój-th element of the vector xùë•x. We define the ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\ell_{p}-norm for p‚â•1ùëù1p\geq 1 as ‚Äñx‚Äñp=(‚àëj=1d|x‚Äã(j)|p)1psubscriptnormùë•ùëùsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëësuperscriptùë•ùëóùëù1ùëù\|x\|_{p}=(\sum_{j=1}^{d}|x(j)|^{p})^{\frac{1}{p}}. We denote that ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•=‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•2\|\cdot\|=\|\cdot\|_{2}, and ‚Äñx‚Äñ‚àû=maxj‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,d}‚Å°|x‚Äã(j)|subscriptnormùë•subscriptùëó1‚Ä¶ùëëùë•ùëó\|x\|_{\infty}=\max_{j\in\{1,...,d\}}|x(j)|. For any function f‚Äã(x)ùëìùë•f(x), we denote f(k)‚Äã(x)superscriptùëìùëòùë•f^{(k)}(x) as its kùëòk-th derivative, and for a vector x=[x‚Äã(1),‚Ä¶,x‚Äã(d)]‚ä§‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscriptùë•1‚Ä¶ùë•ùëëtopsuperscript‚Ñùùëëx=[x(1),...,x(d)]^{\top}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, we define Sign‚Äã(x)=[Sign‚Äã(x‚Äã(1)),‚Ä¶,Sign‚Äã(x‚Äã(d))]‚ä§Signùë•superscriptSignùë•1‚Ä¶Signùë•ùëëtop\text{Sign}(x)=[\text{Sign}(x(1)),...,\text{Sign}(x(d))]^{\top}.

1.1 Related works

Stochastic sign-based method. Our proposed algorithm belongs to this category. Among the existing works [43, 27, 12], the setting considered by [43] is closest to ours since the latter two consider gradient compression not only in the uplink but also in the downlink. Despite of this difference and the use of different convergence metrics, the algorithms therein achieve the same convergence rate O‚Äã(œÑ‚àí14)ùëÇsuperscriptùúè14O(\tau^{-\frac{1}{4}}), where œÑùúè\tau is the total number of gradient queries to the local objective function. Compared to existing works, our proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg requires a slightly stronger assumption on the minibatch gradient noise, but achieves a faster convergence rate O‚Äã(œÑ‚àí13)ùëÇsuperscriptùúè13O(\tau^{-\frac{1}{3}}) or even O‚Äã(œÑ‚àí12)ùëÇsuperscriptùúè12O(\tau^{-\frac{1}{2}}), with the standard squared ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients as the convergence metric.

Error-Feedback method. The error-feedback (EF) method is first proposed by [45] and later theoretically justified by [31]. Then, [50, 47, 46] further extended this EF method into distributed and adaptive gradient schemes. The key idea of the EF-based methods is to show that the sign operator scaled by the gradient norm is a contractive compressor, and the error induced by the contractive compressor can be compensated. However, such EF-based methods cannot deal with partial client participation otherwise the error residuals cannot be correctly tracked. Besides, the EF-based methods have a convergence rate ùí™‚Äã(œÑ‚àí12+d2‚ÄãœÑ‚àí1)ùí™superscriptùúè12superscriptùëë2superscriptùúè1\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{2}}+d^{2}\tau^{-1}), where dùëëd is the dimension of the gradients, and therefore is not competitive for high-dimension problems.

Unbiased quantization method. Apart from the sign-based gradient compression, another popular way of compression is the unbiased stochastic quantization method adopted by [5, 42, 23]. A key assumption made by this category of methods is that the quantization error is bounded by the norm of the input, which however does not hold for sign-based compression, and therefore the existing convergence results therein do not apply to sign-based methods. Besides, as shown in [5, 42], these methods usually have degraded convergence speed when fewer quantization bits are used.

As mentioned, some of the existing sign-based methods like [12, 43] do not adopt the standard squared ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients as the metric for the convergence rate analysis. Thus, it is tricky to make a fair comparison between them and the proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg. In Appendix A, we provide a detailed discussion and summarize the convergence rates of some representative algorithms in Table 2.

2 Sign operator with symmetric and zero-mean noise

In this section, we introduce a general noisy perturbation scheme for the sign-based compression and analyze the asymptotic unbiasedness of compressed gradients. The results serve as the foundation for the proposed algorithms in subsequent sections.

(2)

In other words, the perturbed sign operator is an asymptotically unbiased estimator of the input xùë•x when œÉ‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùúé\sigma\to\infty. Furthermore, assume that p‚Äã(t)ùëùùë°p(t) is uniformly bounded on (‚àí‚àû,+‚àû)(-\infty,+\infty) and differentiable for an arbitrary order. Then, with the Taylor‚Äôs expansion, we can have œÉp‚Äã(0)‚Äã‚à´0xœÉp‚Äã(t)‚Äãùëët=x+1p‚Äã(0)‚Äã‚àëk=1+‚àûp(k)‚Äã(0)‚Äãxk+1(k+1)!‚ÄãœÉk=x+‚àëk=1+‚àûp(k)‚Äã(0)‚Äãùí™‚Äã(œÉ‚àík).ùúéùëù0superscriptsubscript0ùë•ùúéùëùùë°differential-dùë°ùë•1ùëù0superscriptsubscriptùëò1superscriptùëùùëò0superscriptùë•ùëò1ùëò1superscriptùúéùëòùë•superscriptsubscriptùëò1superscriptùëùùëò0ùí™superscriptùúéùëò\frac{\sigma}{p(0)}\int_{0}^{\frac{x}{\sigma}}p(t)dt=x+\frac{1}{p(0)}\sum_{k=1}^{+\infty}\frac{p^{(k)}(0)x^{k+1}}{(k+1)!\sigma^{k}}=x+\sum_{k=1}^{+\infty}p^{(k)}(0)\mathcal{O}\left(\sigma^{-k}\right). Definition 1 (zùëßz-distribution).

A random variable Œæzsubscriptùúâùëß\xi_{z} is said to follow the zùëßz-distribution if its p.d.f is

In addition, one can also show that pz‚Äã(t)subscriptùëùùëßùë°p_{z}(t) converges to the p.d.f of the uniform random variable on the interval [‚àí1,1]11[-1,1] when z‚Üí+‚àû‚Üíùëßz\to+\infty (see Lemma 2 in Appendix B). This zùëßz-distribution has a nice property that can be leveraged to bound the bias caused by the sign-based compression, as stated in the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

For any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} and œÉ>0ùúé0\sigma>0,

where Œæz‚Äã(1),‚Ä¶,Œæz‚Äã(d)subscriptùúâùëß1‚Ä¶subscriptùúâùëßùëë\xi_{z}(1),...,\xi_{z}(d) follow the i.i.d. zùëßz-distribution.

Remark 1.

One can see that the RHS of (4) involves the term (‚Äñx‚Äñ4‚Äãz+2/œÉ)4‚Äãzsuperscriptsubscriptnormùë•4ùëß2ùúé4ùëß\left({\|x\|_{4z+2}}/{\sigma}\right)^{4z}. Thus, as long as œÉ>‚Äñx‚Äñ‚àûùúésubscriptnormùë•\sigma>\|x\|_{\infty}, the LHS of (4) converges to zero when z‚Üí+‚àû‚Üíùëßz\to+\infty. Since Lemma 2 implies that Œæ‚àûsubscriptùúâ\xi_{\infty} follows the i.i.d uniform distribution on [‚àí1,1]11[-1,1], we obtain œÉ‚Äãùîº‚Äã[Sign‚Äã(x+œÉ‚ÄãŒæ‚àû)]=xùúéùîºdelimited-[]Signxùúésubscriptùúâùë•\sigma\mathbb{E}\left[\rm{Sign}(x+\sigma\xi_{\infty})\right]=x as long as œÉ>‚Äñx‚Äñ‚àûùúésubscriptnormùë•\sigma>\|x\|_{\infty}. It is interesting to remark that the stochastic sign operators proposed in [27, 43] are exactly the sign operator injected by the uniform noise, and [12] also considered the use of a symmetric noise for gradient perturbation. Thus, sign-based compression with the zùëßz-distribution offers a unified perspective to understand the relationship among the existing stochastic sign-based methods.

3 zùëßz-SignFedAvg Algorithm

In this section, based on the analysis in Section 2, we propose the following sign-based FedAvg algorithm, termed as zùëßz-SignFedAvg. While FedAvg-type algorithms with gradient compression are also presented in [23], they require unbiased compression and are not applicable to sign-based methods. The details of zùëßz-SignFedAvg are presented in Algorithm 1. A prominent difference between the proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg and the existing sign-based methods lies in that the clients are allowed to perform multiple SGD updates per communication round (E>1ùê∏1E>1) before applying the stochastic sign-based compression. Like the FedAvg algorithm, it is anticipated that zùëßz-SignFedAvg can greatly benefit from this and has a significantly reduced communication cost.

Note that in practice we only consider z=1ùëß1z=1 and z=+‚àûùëßz=+\infty for the zùëßz-SignFedAvg since they correspond to the Gaussian distribution and uniform distribution, respectively. Nevertheless, we are interested in the convergence properties of zùëßz-SignFedAvg for a general positive integer zùëßz as it provides better insights on the role of zùëßz for the convergence rate.

We first state some standard assumptions for problem (1).

Assumption 1.

We assume that each fi‚Äã(x)subscriptùëìùëñùë•f_{i}(x) has the following properties:

  1. A.1

    The minibatch gradient is unbiased and has bounded variance, i.e., ùîº‚Äã[gi‚Äã(x)]=‚àáfi‚Äã(x)ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëîùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•\mathbb{E}[g_{i}(x)]=\nabla f_{i}(x) and ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñgi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚Äñ22]‚â§Œ∂2ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•22superscriptùúÅ2\mathbb{E}[\|g_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(x)\|^{2}_{2}]\leq\zeta^{2}.

  2. A.2

    Each fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} is smooth, i.e., for any x,y‚àà‚Ñùdùë•ùë¶superscript‚Ñùùëëx,y\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, there exists some non-negative constants L1,‚Ä¶,Ldsubscriptùêø1‚Ä¶subscriptùêøùëëL_{1},\ldots,L_{d}, such that f‚Äã(y)‚àíf‚Äã(x)‚â§‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(x),y‚àíx‚ü©+‚àëj=1dLj‚Äã(y‚Äã(j)‚àíx‚Äã(j))22.ùëìùë¶ùëìùë•‚àáùëìùë•ùë¶ùë•superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëësubscriptùêøùëósuperscriptùë¶ùëóùë•ùëó22f(y)-f(x)\leq\langle\nabla f(x),y-x\rangle+\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{d}L_{j}\left(y(j)-x(j)\right)^{2}}{2}.

  3. A.3

    fùëìf is lower bounded, i.e., there exists some constant f‚àósuperscriptùëìf^{*} such that f‚Äã(x)‚â•f‚àó,‚àÄx‚àà‚Ñùd.formulae-sequenceùëìùë•superscriptùëìfor-allùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëf(x)\geq f^{*},\forall x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}.

  4. A.4

    There exists a constant G‚â•0ùê∫0G\geq 0 such that ‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚Äñ‚â§Gnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•ùê∫\|\nabla f_{i}(x)\|\leq G, ‚àÄi=1,‚Ä¶,nfor-allùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõ\forall i=1,...,n, and x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}.

Assumption A.2 is a more fine-grained assumption on the function smoothness than the commonly used one and is also used by [9, 43]. For the convergence rate analysis, we consider two cases, namely, the case with z<+‚àûùëßz<+\infty and the case of z=‚àûùëßz=\infty.

3.1 Case 1: z<+‚àûùëßz<+\infty

As we can see from Lemma 1, there always exists some gradient bias when z<+‚àûùëßz<+\infty. In order to bound it, we further assume that a higher order moment of the minibatch gradient noise is bounded.

Assumption 2.

There exists a constant Qz‚â•0subscriptùëÑùëß0Q_{z}\geq 0 such that for any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, we have

ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñgi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚Äñ4‚Äãz+24‚Äãz+2]‚â§Qz.ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•4ùëß24ùëß2subscriptùëÑùëß\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|g_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(x)\|_{4z+2}^{4z+2}]\leq Q_{z}. (5)

When is the bound non-trivial? Since we assume that the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradient is bounded by Gùê∫G, all the terms in the RHS of (6) should be no larger than G2superscriptùê∫2G^{2}. For example, to have the first term in (6b) less than G2superscriptùê∫2G^{2}, one requires œÉùúé\sigma to be greater than 21+14‚Äãz‚ÄãE‚Äã(Qz/G+G4‚Äãz)14‚Äãz/(2‚Äãz+1)12‚Äãzsuperscript2114ùëßùê∏superscriptsubscriptùëÑùëßùê∫superscriptùê∫4ùëß14ùëßsuperscript2ùëß112ùëß{{2^{1+\frac{1}{4z}}E\left(Q_{z}/G+G^{4z}\right)^{\frac{1}{4z}}}/{(2z+1)^{\frac{1}{2z}}}}.

Bias-variance trade-off. An interesting observation from Theorem 1 is that there exists a trade-off between the bias and variance terms. One can see that the terms in (6b) is caused by the gradient bias of the sign operation (see (4)) and is an infinitesimal of œÉùúé\sigma with ùí™‚Äã(œÉ‚àí2‚Äãz)ùí™superscriptùúé2ùëß\mathcal{O}\left({\sigma^{-2z}}\right), while the term in (6c) is due to the injected noise and is in the order of ùí™‚Äã(Œ≥‚ÄãœÉ2)ùí™ùõæsuperscriptùúé2\mathcal{O}\left({\gamma\sigma^{2}}\right). Specifically, the first term in (6b) only depends on the noise scale œÉùúé\sigma and mostly affects the final objective. Meanwhile, the variance term in (6c) mainly affects the convergence speed because a smaller stepsize is required for it to diminish.

Theoretically, we can choose an iteration-dependent noise scale œÉùúé\sigma so as to make the algorithm converge to a stationary solution. To see this, let us denote œÑ=T‚ÄãEùúèùëáùê∏\tau=TE as the total number of gradient queries per client, and present the following corollary.

Corollary 1 (Informal).

Let œÉ=(n‚ÄãœÑ)14‚Äãz+2ùúésuperscriptùëõùúè14ùëß2\sigma=(n\tau)^{\frac{1}{4z+2}} and Œ≥=min‚Å°{nz2‚Äãz+1‚ÄãœÑ‚àíz+12‚Äãz+1,Lmax‚àí1}ùõæsuperscriptùëõùëß2ùëß1superscriptùúèùëß12ùëß1subscriptsuperscriptùêø1\gamma=\min\{n^{\frac{z}{2z+1}}\tau^{-\frac{z+1}{2z+1}},{L^{-1}_{\max}}\} in Theorem 1, and let E‚â§n‚àí3‚Äãz4‚Äãz+2‚ÄãœÑz+24‚Äãz+2ùê∏superscriptùëõ3ùëß4ùëß2superscriptùúèùëß24ùëß2E\leq n^{-\frac{3z}{4z+2}}\tau^{\frac{z+2}{4z+2}}. We have

ùîº‚Äã[1œÑ‚Äã‚àët=1T‚àës=1E‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(x¬Øt‚àí1,s‚àí1)‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]1ùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë†1ùê∏superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsubscript¬Øùë•ùë°1ùë†12\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{s=1}^{E}\|\nabla f(\bar{x}_{t-1,s-1})\|^{2}\right] =ùí™‚Äã((n‚ÄãœÑ)‚àíz2‚Äãz+1).absentùí™superscriptùëõùúèùëß2ùëß1\displaystyle=\mathcal{O}\left((n\tau)^{-\frac{z}{2z+1}}\right). (7)

Achieveing linear speedup. From Corollary 1, we can see that the zùëßz-SignFedAvg needs (n‚ÄãœÑ)3‚Äãz4‚Äãz+2superscriptùëõùúè3ùëß4ùëß2(n\tau)^{\frac{3z}{4z+2}} communication rounds to achieve a linear-speedup convergence rate. Particularly, when z=1ùëß1z=1, the corresponding convergence rate is ùí™‚Äã((n‚ÄãœÑ)‚àí13)ùí™superscriptùëõùúè13\mathcal{O}((n\tau)^{-\frac{1}{3}}) and the required communication rounds is (n‚ÄãœÑ)12superscriptùëõùúè12(n\tau)^{\frac{1}{2}}. To the best of our knowledge, the previous works have never shown the sign-based method can achieve a linear-speedup convergence rate.

Relationship to [12]. The work [12] also considered the use of a symmetric and zero-mean noise for the sign-based compression and proved that the algorithm has a convergence rate ùí™‚Äã(œÑ‚àí14)ùí™superscriptùúè14\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{4}}). However, their results have three differences from our zùëßz-SignFedAvg and Theorem 1. First, [12] considered gradient compression both in the uplink and downlink communications. In addition, the convergence metric they used is not the standard squared ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients and is hard to interpret. Second, their analysis is rooted in the median-based algorithm, whereas we judiciously exploit the property of the sign operation and hence provide a general analysis framework for the stochastic sign-based methods. Last but not the least, unlike our zùëßz-SignFedAvg, [12] cannot allow multiple local SGD updates.

3.2 Case 2: z=+‚àûùëßz=+\infty

When z=+‚àûùëßz=+\infty, the injected noise Œæzsubscriptùúâùëß\xi_{z} in the zùëßz-SignFedAvg is uniformly distributed on [‚àí1,1]11[-1,1]. From Remark 1, we have learned that the gradient bias can vanish as long as the noise scale œÉùúé\sigma is sufficiently large. To quantify this threshold, we need the following assumption which is a limit form of Assumption 2.

Assumption 3.

There exists a constant Q‚àû‚â•0subscriptùëÑ0Q_{\infty}\geq 0 such that for any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, with probability 1,

‚Äñgi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚Äñ‚àû‚â§Q‚àû.subscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•subscriptùëÑ\displaystyle\|g_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(x)\|_{\infty}\leq Q_{\infty}. (8)
Theorem 2.

(Informal) Suppose that Assumption 1 and 3 hold. For Œ≥=min‚Å°{n12‚ÄãœÑ‚àí12,Lmax‚àí1}ùõæsuperscriptùëõ12superscriptùúè12subscriptsuperscriptùêø1\gamma=\min\{n^{\frac{1}{2}}\tau^{-\frac{1}{2}},{L^{-1}_{\max}}\}, Œ∑=œÉùúÇùúé\eta=\sigma, z=+‚àûùëßz=+\infty, E‚â§n‚àí34‚ÄãœÑ14ùê∏superscriptùëõ34superscriptùúè14E\leq n^{-\frac{3}{4}}\tau^{\frac{1}{4}} and œÉ>E‚Äã(G+Q‚àû)ùúéùê∏ùê∫subscriptùëÑ\sigma>E(G+Q_{\infty}) in Algorithm 1 we have

ùîº‚Äã[1œÑ‚Äã‚àët=1T‚àës=1E‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(x¬Øt‚àí1,s‚àí1)‚Äñ2]ùîºdelimited-[]1ùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëásuperscriptsubscriptùë†1ùê∏superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsubscript¬Øùë•ùë°1ùë†12\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{s=1}^{E}\|\nabla f(\bar{x}_{t-1,s-1})\|^{2}\right] =ùí™‚Äã((n‚ÄãœÑ)‚àí12).absentùí™superscriptùëõùúè12\displaystyle=\mathcal{O}\left((n\tau)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right). (9)

However, if œÉ‚â§E‚Äã(G+Q‚àû)ùúéùê∏ùê∫subscriptùëÑ\sigma\leq E(G+Q_{\infty}), there exists a problem instance for which Algorithm 1 cannot converge.

Remark 2.

Note that Theorem 2 implies that ‚àû\infty-SignFedAvg has a matching convergence rate as the uncompressed FedAvg. The reason why ‚àû\infty-SignFedAvg cannot converge when œÉ‚â§E‚Äã(G+Q‚àû)ùúéùê∏ùê∫subscriptùëÑ\sigma\leq E(G+Q_{\infty}) is simply that the uniform noise has a finite support and cannot always change the sign of gradients. For example, if œÉ<Aùúéùê¥\sigma<A for some A>0ùê¥0A>0, then we have Sign‚Äã(x+œÉ‚ÄãŒæ‚àû)=Sign‚Äã(x)Signùë•ùúésubscriptùúâSignùë•\text{\rm Sign}(x+\sigma\xi_{\infty})=\text{\rm Sign}(x) for any x‚â•Aùë•ùê¥x\geq A.

Relationship to [27, 43]. As mentioned in Remark 1, both the stochastic sign operators in [27, 43] are equivalent to the sign operator injected by the uniform noise. Nevertheless, there are still two distinctions when compared with our ‚àû\infty-SignFedAvg. First, while [43] shows their algorithm has a ùí™‚Äã(œÑ‚àí14)ùí™superscriptùúè14\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{4}}) convergence rate, it is based on the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients and cannot imply the same rate as that in (9) (see Appendix A). Second, although [43] does not need Assumption 3, it relies on an input-dependent noise scale which, unfortunately, often slows the algorithm convergence in practice especially when the problem dimension is large.

More theoretical results and proofs are relegated to Appendix B and C. Below, we have two more remarks.

Remark 3.

(Bounded minibatch gradient noise) While both Assumption 2 and 3 are slightly stronger than the commonly used second-order condition on the minibatch gradient noise, they are still justifiable since unbounded minibatch gradient noise is rarely to happen in practice.

Remark 4.

(Minibatch gradient noise works as noise perturbation) When the minibatch gradient is used as the input of the sign operator in (2), the minibatch gradient noise itself may function as the perturbation noise. In particular, as shown in [13] the minibatch gradient noise approximately follows a symmetric distribution. Therefore, in practice, one may not need to inject as large noises as suggested by Theorem 2 since the minibatch gradient noise can also help mitigate the bias due to sign-based compression. This also explains why a small noise scale is sufficient for zzz-SignFedAvg to achieve good performance in the experiment section.

3.3 Comparison of Case 1 and Case 2

We summarize the results of Case 1 and Case 2 in Table 1, where O~‚Äã(‚ãÖ)~ùëÇ‚ãÖ\widetilde{O}(\cdot) hides some constants that do not affect the comparison. Especially, we can see that when the mini-batch gradient noise has a long tail such that Qz/G‚â™Q‚àû4‚Äãzmuch-less-thansubscriptùëÑùëßùê∫superscriptsubscriptùëÑ4ùëßQ_{z}/G\ll Q_{\infty}^{4z}, Case 1 requires a less amount of noise than Case 2 for guaranteeing convergence. Despite of the difference in theory, we will see in Section 4 that zùëßz-SignFedAvg under Case 1 and Case 2 have almost the same behavior in practice.

3.4 Implication on Differentially Private Federated Learning (DP-FL)

Beyond the convergence issue, adding Gaussian noise to the local gradients is also a common practice for privacy protection, especially in DP-FL [21, 3, 4]. With this observation, it is straightforward to propose a differentially-private variant of zùëßz-SignFedAvg, which we term DP-SignFedAvg. More details and comparison results between DP-SignFedAvg and the uncompressed DP-FedAvg [21, 28] under different privacy budgets are given in Appendix F.

4 Experiments

In this section, we present the experiment results on both synthetic and real problems, and all the figures in this section are obtained by 10 independent runs and are visualized in the form of mean¬±plus-or-minus\pmstd.

Noise scale as a hyperparameter. Although we explicitly characterize how the performance of zùëßz-SignFedAvg depends on the noise scale œÉùúé\sigma in the previous section, we treat œÉùúé\sigma as a tunable hyperparameter in the experiments. This is because, on one hand, the theoretical lower bound for œÉùúé\sigma are difficult to compute since it is impossible to access the moment condition of the minibatch gradient noise. On the other hand, as we have discussed in Remark 4, owing to the presence of the minibatch gradient noise, we can use a much smaller noise scale than the theoretical one in practice.

Aside from the experiments presented in this section, we also compare our algorithm to another popular family of unbiased stochastic compressed FL algorithms, namely, the QSGD in [5] and FedPAQ in [42]. For detailed results, we refer readers to Appendix E.

4.1 A simple consensus problem

In this section, we verify our theoretical results in Section 3 by considering the simple consensus problem with 10 clients: minx‚àà‚Ñùd‚Å°12‚Äã‚àëi=110‚Äñx‚àíyi‚Äñ2,subscriptùë•superscript‚Ñùùëë12superscriptsubscriptùëñ110superscriptnormùë•subscriptùë¶ùëñ2\min_{x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}}\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{10}\|x-y_{i}\|^{2}, where y1,‚Ä¶,y10‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶10superscript‚Ñùùëëy_{1},...,y_{10}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} are generated using i.i.d standard Gaussian distribution, and dùëëd is the problem dimension. We implemented the following algorithms: GD (Gradient descent), Sto-SignSGD [43], SignSGD (Algorithm 1 with z=1ùëß1z=1, E=1ùê∏1E=1 and œÉ=0ùúé0\sigma=0), 111-SignSGD (Algorithm 1 with z=1ùëß1z=1 and E=1ùê∏1E=1.), ‚àû\infty-SignSGD (Algorithm 1 with z=+‚àûùëßz=+\infty and E=1ùê∏1E=1). For all the algorithms, we considered the full gradient (no minibatch SGD), and used the same stepsize 0.010.010.01 and initialization by a zero vector.

Results. As we can see from Figure 1, the vanilla SignSGD fails to converge to the optimal solution whereas the others can. Besides, 111-SignSGD and ‚àû\infty-SignSGD have roughly the same convergence speed which is slightly slower than the uncompressed GD. It is also observed that the input-dependent noise scale adopted by [43] could slow the convergence when the problem dimension is high, as discussed in Section 3.2.

Figure 2 displays the results of 111-SignSGD and ‚àû\infty-SignSGD with various noise scales. We can see that there is a clear bias-variance trade-off for different noise scales and it corroborates our analysis after Theorem 1. It is also worth mentioning that the best choice of œÉùúé\sigma for Algorithm 1 shown in Figure 2 is much smaller than the one predicted by the theorems.

4.2 zùëßz-SignSGD on Non-i.i.d MNIST

In this section, we consider an extremely non-i.i.d setting with the MNIST dataset [17]. Specifically, we split the dataset into 10 parts based on the labels and each client has the data of one digit only. A simple two-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) from Pytorch tutorial [40] was used. The following algorithms were implemented: SGDwM (Distributed SGD [22] with momentum), EF-SignSGDwM (Distributed SignSGD with error-feedback and momentum [31, 50]), and Sto-SignSGDwM (Sto-SignSGD with momentum [43]). For each of the algorithms, we selected its best hyperparameters, including the stepsize, momentum coefficient and the noise scale, via grid search (see Appendix D.1).

Results. One can observe from Figure 3(a)-3(b) that again the vanilla SignSGD does not converge well. The proposed 111-SignSGD and ‚àû\infty-SignSGD clearly outperform the existing EF-SignSGDwM and Sto-SignSGDw, and perform closely to the uncompressed SGDwM. The reason for the slow convergence of Sto-SignSGDw is that the injected noise is too large due to the input-dependent noise scale. Figure 3(c) further displays the testing accuracy of all methods versus the accumulated number of bits transmitted from the clients to the server. One can see that the proposed algorithms achieve the state-of-the-art performance on this task. More results for 111-SignSGD and ‚àû\infty-SignSGD under different noise scales are presented in Appendix D.1.

4.3 zùëßz-SignFedAvg on EMNIST and CIFAR-10

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg on two classical datasets: EMNIST[15] and CIFAR-10 [33]. In particular, the proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg with z=1ùëß1z=1 and z=‚àûùëßz=\infty are benchmarked against the uncompressed FedAvg [37, 55]. Since 111-SignFedAvg and ‚àû\infty-SignFedAvg behave similarly, we only report the results of 111-SignFedAvg in this section and relegate the others to Appendix D.2. For EMNIST, we use the same 2-layer CNN as the one in Section 4.2. For CIFAR-10, we used the ResNet18 [24] with group normalization [54].

Settings. For both the experiments on EMNIST and CIFAR-10, we followed a setting similar to [41]. We also considered the scenario with partial client participation. For the EMNIST dataset, there are 3579 clients in total and 100 clients were uniformly sampled in each communication round to upload their compressed gradients. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, the training samples are partitioned among 100 clients, and each client has an associated multinomial distribution over labels drawn from a symmetric Dirichlet distribution with parameter 1. In each communication round, 10 out of 100 clients were uniformly sampled. The same noise scales for 111-SignFedAvg and ‚àû\infty-SignFedAvg were used: œÉ=0.01ùúé0.01\sigma=0.01 for EMNIST and œÉ=0.0005ùúé0.0005\sigma=0.0005 for CIFAR-10. More details about the hyperparameters are referred to Appendix D.2.

Results. We can see from Figure 5 that both uncompressed FedAvg and 111-SignFedAvg can benefit from multiple local SGD steps. More surprisingly, 111-SignFedAvg can even outperform the uncompressed FedAvg. This is probably because the EMNIST dataset is less heterogeneous than the one we used in Section 4.2. The results on the performance of 111-SignFedAvg and ‚àû\infty-SignFedAvg under various choices of noise scales are relegated to Appendix D.2, which are also consistent with our theoretical claims in Section 3.

4.4 Plateau Criterion for tuning the noise scale

From previous experiments, we have learned that the noise scale œÉùúé\sigma has to be properly chosen for the algorithm to perform well. However, it could be time-consuming to select the optimal noise scale via grid search. Therefore, here we introduce a simple yet useful strategy that can tune the noise scale adaptively during the training process. Figure 2 indicates that the noise scale should plays a similar role as the stepsize when training a neural network: Small noise scale leads to fast convergence at the beginning, while large noise scale guarantees a better final performance. This suggests that we should use an increasing noise scale during the optimization process. We can also see this from Corollary 1 because that the noise scale œÉùúé\sigma is proportional to œÑùúè\tau. Besides, it has been shown that the gradients of neural network tend to be sparser during the training process [31]. Therefore, as studied in [26], from the rate-distortion theoretic aspect, the noise scale should be increasing as the compression becomes more aggressive. Motivated by all of these insights, we propose the following Plateau criterion for adapting the noise scale.

Plateau criterion. We denote a few parameters œÉbound‚â•œÉinit>0subscriptùúéboundsubscriptùúéinit0\sigma_{\text{bound}}\geq\sigma_{\text{init}}>0, Œ∫‚àà‚Ñ§+ùúÖsubscript‚Ñ§\kappa\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{+}, Œ≤>0ùõΩ0\beta>0. We first start Algorithm 1 with a small noise scale œÉinitsubscriptùúéinit\sigma_{\text{init}}, i.e., œÉ=œÉinitùúésubscriptùúéinit\sigma=\sigma_{\text{init}}, and then update the noise scale via œÉ=Œ≤‚ÄãœÉùúéùõΩùúé\sigma=\beta\sigma, where Œ≤‚àà[1.5,2]ùõΩ1.52\beta\in[1.5,2], whenever the objective function stops improving for Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa communication rounds. We stop updating œÉùúé\sigma if it has already been greater than a relatively large number œÉboundsubscriptùúébound\sigma_{\text{bound}}.

Results. We demonstrate the efficacy of the Plateau criterion by comparing the performance of 111-SignSGD/111-SignFedAvg with the optimal noise scale found in previous experiments and the ones with Plateau criterion. Figure 6 shows the results under the three different settings used in Section 4.2 and 4.3. We can see that, the Plateau criterion could results in a slower convergence speed than the optimal noise scale in the middle phase of optimization, because it requires some time for the algorithm to adapt to a suitable noise scale. But eventually it can lead to the same objective value obtained by using the optimal noise scale. For more details like the hyperparameters for Plateau criterion and the evolution of noise scale, we refer readers to Appendix D.3.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we have proposed the zùëßz-SignFedAvg: a FedAvg-type algorithm with the stochastic sign-based compression. Thanks to the novel noisy perturbation scheme in Section 2, the proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg provides a unified viewpoint to the existing sign-based methods as well as a general framework for convergence rate analysis. Through both theoretical analyses and empirical experiments, we have shown that the zùëßz-SignFedAvg can perform nearly the same, sometimes even better, than the uncompressed FedAvg and enjoy a significant reduction in the number of bits transmitted from clients to the server. As a final remark, the stochastic sign-based compression proposed in this work can be of independent interest and can be conveniently combined with other adaptive FL algorithms or gradient sparsification techniques such as those in [30, 41, 8], to further improve the communication efficiency.

Appendix

A Comparison with existing stochastic sign-based methods

Table 2 summarizes the key features of a few representative stochastic sign-based methods and the proposed zùëßz-SignFedAvg, including the convergence rate, metric used in the convergence rate analysis, extra assumptions other than A.1-A.3 in Assumption 1, and whether the algorithm can achieve linear speedup and allow multiple local SGD steps.

For communication complexity, we focus on the uplink communication cost, i.e., the number of bits transmitted from the clients to the server in each communication round. We assume that all the uncompressed algorithms use 32 bits to represent a single float number as it is the most common setting in Tensorflow [1] and Pytorch [40].

While most of the existing methods use the squared ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients as the convergence metric, the work [43] adopts the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients. The work [12] uses a convergence metric mixed with squared ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm and ‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñì1\ell_{1}-norm of gradients due to the compression in both uplink and downlink .

Among the works in Table 2, the setting considered by [43] is closest to ours. [43] proposed an algorithm that can achieve the convergence rate ùí™‚Äã(œÑ‚àí14)ùí™superscriptùúè14\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{4}}) with the ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients as the metric. We remark that this is inferior to the convergence rate ùí™‚Äã(œÑ‚àí12)ùí™superscriptùúè12\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{2}}) with the squared ‚Ñì2subscript‚Ñì2\ell_{2}-norm as the metric. Except for the previous sign-based compression methods, another type of compressed FL algorithms, such as [5] and [23], adopt a unified unbiased compressor Q‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëÑ‚ãÖQ(\cdot) that satisfies ùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñQ‚Äã(x)‚àíx‚Äñ2]‚â§C‚Äã‚Äñx‚Äñ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormùëÑùë•ùë•2ùê∂superscriptnormùë•2\mathbb{E}[\|Q(x)-x\|^{2}]\leq C\|x\|^{2} for some constant C>0ùê∂0C>0. A specific example of such unbiased compressor is described below.

In Table 2, we assume both [5] and [23] adopt the quantizer in (14). Generally speaking, this type of unbiased quantization usually requires much more bits than sign-based compression to obtain a good performance, which is also verified empirically in Appendix E. It is also worthwhile to mention that the FedPAQ in [42] and the FedCOM in [23] are equivalent in algorithm, but only the latter one considers the heterogeneous scenario theoretically.

B Detailed theoretical results

We first state the result on the limit of zùëßz-distribution.

Lemma 2.

The zùëßz-distribution weakly converges to uniform distribution on [‚àí1,1]11[-1,1] when z‚Üí+‚àû‚Üíùëßz\to+\infty.

The following corollary is the formal version of Corollary 1.

Corollary 2 (Formal version of Corollary 1).

C.3 Proof of Theorem 1

We denote the aggregated update x¬Øt=x¬Øt‚àí1,E.subscript¬Øùë•ùë°subscript¬Øùë•ùë°1ùê∏\bar{x}_{t}=\bar{x}_{t-1,E}. First, we state two technical lemmas:

Lemma 4.

ùîº‚Äã[f‚Äã(xt)‚àíf‚Äã(x¬Øt)]‚â§ùîºdelimited-[]ùëìsubscriptùë•ùë°ùëìsubscript¬Øùë•ùë°absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(x_{t})-f(\bar{x}_{t})]\leq Œ≥‚Äã22‚Äãz‚ÄãE2‚Äãz+1‚ÄãQz+G4‚Äãz+2‚ÄãG2‚Äã(2‚Äãz+1)‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äãz+Œ≥2‚Äã24‚Äãz‚ÄãE4‚Äãz+2‚Äã(Qz+G4‚Äãz+2)‚ÄãLmax4‚Äã(2‚Äãz+1)2‚ÄãœÉ4‚Äãzùõæsuperscript22ùëßsuperscriptùê∏2ùëß1subscriptùëÑùëßsuperscriptùê∫4ùëß2ùê∫22ùëß1superscriptùúé2ùëßsuperscriptùõæ2superscript24ùëßsuperscriptùê∏4ùëß2subscriptùëÑùëßsuperscriptùê∫4ùëß2subscriptùêø4superscript2ùëß12superscriptùúé4ùëß\displaystyle\frac{\gamma 2^{2z}E^{2z+1}\sqrt{Q_{z}+G^{4z+2}}G}{\sqrt{2}(2z+1)\sigma^{2z}}+\frac{\gamma^{2}2^{4z}E^{4z+2}(Q_{z}+G^{4z+2})L_{\max}}{4(2z+1)^{2}\sigma^{4z}}

Proof of Lemma 6.

To prove this lemma, we need to use a classical result on the monotonicity of ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\ell_{p} norm:

Lemma 7.

[29] For any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} and 1<r<p1ùëüùëù1<r<p, we have

‚Äñx‚Äñp‚â§‚Äñx‚Äñr‚â§d1r‚àí1p‚Äã‚Äñx‚Äñp.subscriptnormùë•ùëùsubscriptnormùë•ùëüsuperscriptùëë1ùëü1ùëùsubscriptnormùë•ùëù\displaystyle\|x\|_{p}\leq\|x\|_{r}\leq d^{\frac{1}{r}-\frac{1}{p}}\|x\|_{p}. (49)

Now from the definition of ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\ell_{p} norm we have

E Comparison with unbiased stochastic quantization method

In this part, we compare our Algorithm 1 to the QSGD [5] along with its extension to FedAvg, i.e., FedPAQ [42]. As we have shown that zùëßz-SignSGD/zùëßz-SignFedAvg with the Gaussian noise and uniform noise behave very closely, here we only consider 111-SignSGD/111-SignFedAvg for comparison. We use the unbiased quantizer in (14) for both QSGD and FedPAQ.

We can see that the quantization level sùë†s plays as a key role in the performance and communication efficiency of QSGD and FedPAQ. In a rough sense, sùë†s also represents the number of bits needed to transmit for a single coordinate. Thus, we will compare our algorithms to them with different choices of sùë†s. We remark that, even in the most extreme case, i.e., s=1ùë†1s=1, it still needs three alphabets ‚àí1,1,0110-1,1,0 for communication, while sign-based method only uses ‚àí11-1 and 111.

Setting. Again, we consider the three different datasets used in Section 4.2 and 4.2. Specifically, we compare the 111-SignSGD with QSGD on the non-i.i.d. MNIST dataset, and compare 111-SignFedAvg with FedPAQ on EMNIST and CIFAR-10. For all the algorithms, the client‚Äôs stepsize and batchsize are set to the same values used in Section 4.2 and 4.2. For 111-SignSGD/111-SignFedAvg, we reuse the previously found optimal hyperparameters. For QSGD, we tune the server stepsize via grid search on [0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005]0.10.050.010.005[0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005]. For FedPAQ, we tune the server stepsize via grid search on [1,0.5,0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005]10.50.10.050.010.005[1,0.5,0.1,0.05,0.01,0.005]. The chosen server stepsizes for QSGD and FedPAQ under three datesets are presented in Table 7.

Results. From Figure 16, we can see that, our proposed sign-based compressor is consistently superior to the unbiased stochastic quantization method in low precision region (1 bit to 8 bits), except the only case that QSGD with s=4ùë†4s=4 is slightly better than our 111-SignSGD on the non-i.i.d MNIST dataset. These results again, as [9, 31] did, show that the biased compressor, or more specifically the sign-based compressor, can be a strong competitor to those unbiased quantizer due to reduced variance. Our contribution in this work is to provide a generic framework that bridges the unbiased compressor and the biased one, which allows one to conveniently seek an optimal trade-off between the compression bias and variance.

F Differential Private Federated Learning on EMNIST

Let us first review the definition of DP.

Definition 3 (Approximate DP [19]).

A randomized algorithm MùëÄM that takes as input a dataset consisting of individuals is (Œµ,Œ¥)ùúÄùõø(\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private if for any pair of datasets SùëÜS,S‚Ä≤superscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤S^{\prime} that differ in the record of a single individual, and for any event Eùê∏E,

‚Ñô‚Äã[M‚Äã(S)‚ààE]‚©ΩeŒµ‚Äã‚Ñô‚Äã[M‚Äã(S‚Ä≤)‚ààE]+Œ¥.‚Ñôdelimited-[]ùëÄùëÜùê∏superscripteùúÄ‚Ñôdelimited-[]ùëÄsuperscriptùëÜ‚Ä≤ùê∏ùõø\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[M(S)\in E]\leqslant\mathrm{e}^{\varepsilon}\mathbb{P}\left[M\left(S^{\prime}\right)\in E\right]+\delta. (73)

The value ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon is regarded as the privacy budget, and the smaller it is the stronger privacy the algorithm provides. The quantity Œ¥ùõø\delta is usually set to 1n1ùëõ\frac{1}{n}. The most popular mechanism to achieve DP is the Gaussian mechanism [19]. Specifically, similar to [3, 28], here we consider client-level DP guarantee for Federated Learning, i.e, we regard each client as a single data point in Definition 3. Besides, we also adopt the local version of DP gurantee, i.e., each dataset in Definition 3 contains only one data point. Such DP guarantee do not assume that the server is trustworthy and hence is commonly used in practice [3, 28]. For more details on DP and its application in FL, we refer readers to [19, 38, 2, 21].

Here we describe the differential private version of Algorithm 1, which we term DP-SignFedAvg (Algorithm 2). The only difference between DP-SignFedAvg and zùëßz-SignFedAvg is that z=1ùëß1z=1 is chosen (Gaussian noise), and the norm of local gradients is clipped before perturbing it by the noise and applying the sign compression. To obtain the client-level privacy guarantee, we adopt the privacy accounting method in [39].

Now we investigate the empirical performance of the DP-SignFedAvg on EMNIST, and compared it with the uncompressed DP-FedAvg used in [3, 28].

Settings. We followed a setting similar to [28] for the experiment on EMNIST. We adopted the client-level differential privacy, i.e., to treat each client as a single data point, and perturbed the local gradients before sending them to server. We also used the technique of privacy amplification by client sub-sampling in [28, 21]. For both DP-FedAvg and DP-SignFedAvg, the same CNN in Section 4.2 was used, and the maximum norm for clipping was set to 0.01. We sampled 100 clients at each communication round and ran both algorithms for 500 communication rounds. Similar to [28], we run the experiments under the privacy budgets Œµ=[1,2,4,6,8,10]ùúÄ1246810\varepsilon=[1,2,4,6,8,10]. In Table 8, we provide the hyperparameter for DP-FedAvg and DP-SignFedAvg for all levels of privacy budgets. Unlike previous experiments, the noise scales used in this experiment were determined by the privacy budget and the privacy accounting method in [39].

Results. It can be seen from Figure 17 that DP-SignFedAvg is only slightly inferior to the uncompressed DP-FedAvg for various levels of privacy budget. It is worthy to note that the work [28] conducted a similar experiment and showed that the compressed DP-FedAvg with 12 bits for each gradient coordinate can be far worse than the uncompressed DP-FedAvg. It is a strong contrast to our DP-SignFedAvg which uses only 1 bit for each coordinate.
